bibl.title: Despatches from United States Consuls in Boma, 1888-1895
bibl.publisher: National Archives and Records Service General Services Administration

div1.p:
US Consulate Goree Dakar July 13th 1880
To the Honorable James D Porter Assistant Secretary of State Washington
Sir Before discussing the subject of the appointment of a successor for Mr. Armand, I desire respectfully to call the attention of the Department with a view to some explanation of the enclosed copies of letters received at this Consulate form the Legation at Paris. It will be seen thereby that my request for a leave of absence to visit America preferred in my Despatch No. 21 and sebt Feburary 18th not with an unqualified refusal and until I know the grounds
hardly be esteemed unreasonable by the Department that I should be held too closely by a Consulate which excarcely pays for the veriling it initals.

Regarding a Successor for Mr. Command I know of no person in Goree who would exactly answer. The nearest appraoch to it would be Chales de Manfort by the present Mayor of Goree who understands the English language suffiencently will and is faulters as to business qualifications and Character but holding many colonial office he is compelled to be much of the time absent. The only other suitable person that I proves of in my San Searge Strickland such is noe on a visit name to being out my family

of that refusal I am at a loss in preferring another request which in the not distant future may be absolutely necessary for me. If it was thought that I asked for a visit too protracted, I have only to urge custom, the extreme precautions taken by naval vessels while navigating seen in the good reason on this coast, and above all the malancholy fate of my colleague Mr. Armand, whose death was caused solely by blood posioning from maria. Though habituated to extreme Southern Cattuder for the last twenty-five years I am suffering some form the same cause. I have not been six months away from Africa in eight years, and with this fact in view it can

and I expect him have early in September. It is not perhaps delicate for a father to recommend his cover San, and I shall not so so only to state facts which under the circumstances may be acted on or not as the Department shall think proper. He is 21 yeats of age, was born in New London, Connecticeit, has been literally educated both classically + commercially writes an elegant hand and can both speak and write the French language with facility. He was with me here all of last increase and has allogate lived as many as three years in Africa. He has also been in France, England and several voyages
with me at sea mostly however when he was very young. At to political opinions neither of as have can any by means of a late not from perhaps but principalty from lack of .

My father however was a life long Commerical, and I have always been caussions of same bias that easy: not enough however to make me follow that or any party in measures which an being fairly examined my judgement or conscience would condemn.

my partion with regard to the Consulate is this: as it same without seeking an my part so, I am proposed to port with it as lightly if it shall so seen expresed for the Government. If however it is still intrusted to me

I shall continue to the both which may ability with same close transportation to the mission sail allow. For me to matte accountant visits about the Coast in composture and it is also necesarry that I should easy to arrange no that this Consulate will that be repeated and with one apology for there extended extermies I am for with respect Very Truly Yours Peter Strickland U.S. Consul
